text: A small, mod apartment (high-rise, city lights, etc.). We're at a party: with-it people in cocktail clothes, most of them slender, the women playing up bodies. Liquor, dishes of nuts, pretzels, candy on every table. UNDER THE TITLES and STAR CAST CREDITS: The hostess, PATTY, very thin and sexy, refills drinks, serves rich hors d'oeuvres to the guests who are in- volved in a game of charades. Most guests take some- thing, a few refuse. PHIL, very macho, acts out the book title: "LOOKING OUT FOR #1." AD LIBS of... "seeking," "searching," "looking"... "Looking, looking" ... etc, During that we BECOME AWARE of certain of the guests: MARGE, rather rolly-polly, tires of the game, takes hors d'oeuvres tray to help Patty.
Let me help, Patty.

Oh, thanks, Marge. Marge eats a few as she passes them around. JACK, mid-thirties, slim, nice-looking, just beginning to bald, is more interested in the very young redhead beside him than in the game -- and she in him. On Jack's other side, VICKY, Jack's wife, quite overweight, wearing a too-tight pantsuit, but very atractive and vivacious, steals a disapproving look at Jack, and then turns back to the game. Phil is now pointing to him- self and gesturing "1." TITLES END.
"Looking Out For Number 1!’ AD LIB applause and agreement. Patty hands an hors d'oeuvre tray to Phil, as she kisses him.
Brilliant, Phil, darling. Now you can be host again. During that, Vicky polishes off a handful of nuts, and gets up to be next. She takes the folded paper that's handed to her, reads it. (CONTINUED)
Oh, no! Oh, come on! This sounds like something my husband would dream up. (to Jack) Jack, did you? Jack glances at her, shakes his head, no, and goes back to the redhead. Vicky watches until:

Come on, Vicky, start. AD LIB urging, and Vicky gestures that she's starting. She makes the proper gestures for AD LIBBED reactions: "Book title’... "Five words"... "Non-fiction"... "com- plete title"... Vicky begins to run in place. AD LIBS: "Hurry"... "Chase"... "race"... Vicky gestures "keep trying"... as she runs toward Jack, runs in place in front of him, until --

(turning toward her) Run? She gestures "yes," and to keep trying... and runs harder -- as Jack turns back to the redhead. Vicky notes that, disapproving, and then is drawn back to the game. AD LIBS: “Run, Spot, Run?"... "Maybe it's not run," etc., as Patty and Marge pass food trays and Phil refills wine glasses. He pours for a PAUNCHY MAN.
I hope it's dry wine. Dry has less calories.
Drink up. You can fast tomorrow. Patty, turning to the game:
"Run For Your Life’? Vicky gestures no, try again... and runs harder, really lifting her legs, and racing hard in place. She ges- tures a full circle with her arms.
We're BEHIND her as: (CONTINUED)

I've got it, I've got it! ‘The Complete Book of Running'! Applause. Vicky takes a deep, thankful bow and -- her pants split -- in full view of those behind her. There's an awkward silence as those who don't see it react to those who do. Vicky stands, frozen for a moment. Jack is embarrassed, turns away from the red-~ head. And then. Vicky grins widely (a facade), turns so everyone can see the ripped pants, and throws her hands up in a champion's gesture.
The winner and new champion, Vicky Matthews! The room erupts into applause and laughter. Jack re- laxes, and turns his attention back to the redhead.

A glamorous bedroom, with one corner used as a sewing room -- materials and supplies neatly stashed in cubbyholes over a sewing machine, with a slender form wearing a half-finished disco dress standing next to it. Vicky is easing out of the torn pants, as Patty goes through her clothes in the closet. She takes out various items, a dress, a pair of pants, a robe, all sexy, all too small for Vicky, as --
Why did you invite the redhead?
I didn't. Phil did.
So why doesn't she hit on Phil?
She likes husbands better. than boyfriends. How about this? Showing Vicky a filmy robe.
Oh, sure! Patty, none of that is going to fit me. (CONTINUED)
Vicky wraps the torn pants around herself, and goes to the sewing machine.
(continuing) Why don't you make yourself a caftan?
I don't like them. They camouflage everything.
(patting her hip) Yeah... everything. She goes through the pile of neatly folded materials.
Phil likes me in tight, revealing clothes.
Everything I have is tight, and revealing. Of course, none of it started out that way. {picks up a piece of material with a loud, splashy print) Hey, how about.
Vicky! That's for my new couch cover.
Perfect for me.
MUSIC is PLAYING now, and people standing around talk- ing, eating, as Vicky appears in a "sari" made of the bright, splashy print.
Ta-da! Vicky holds a model's pose -- gets applause and laugh- ter from those around her... and a glare from Jack. Then he turns back to the redhead. (CONTINUED)
Vicky sees that, the smile drops and she moves to the hors d'oeuvres table. Marge is there, relishing the pastries.
The cream puffs are great. Vicky nods and takes one -- and a drink in her other hand -- all with an "I'll show you" determination.
Jack drives a large Oldsmobile sedan, and Vicky, still in the sari, sits beside him. Both are angry. The car RADIO counterpoints with romantic MUSIC.
IL think I look very... exotic.
You look like you couldn't find anything big enough in Patty's closet.
(comically) Poor girl is just skin and bones. They ride a moment, silently. The MUSIC ENDS, and a commercial comes on: A.JINGLE advertising a well- known candy. Vicky flicks OFF the RADIO.
(continuing; digging) And you don't like your women bony. You like them popping out of their clothes. She makes a simpery, sexy gesture.
All right, Vicky --
(imitating him) All I did was talk to the girl.
(exactly the same way) All I did was talk -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Cc)
(a take, realizes) She's a nice girl.
If you happen to like sexy looking broads.
I married a sexy looking broad. He looks at her accusingly. Vicky flinches under it, looks for a retort, then --
Well... well... I married a guy with hair on his head. Jack's hand goes automatically to his head to cover a thin spot.

A suburban, upper-middle class house. A vintage Ford coupe is parked to one side of the driveway, almost blocking the other side. The Oldsmobile pulls in off the street, has to angle around the Ford, going onto the grass, before it can get to the garage.
Your mother didn't move her car. Didn't you tell her?
I told her. The garage door opens automatically, revealing a late model Chevy wagon, parked behind the Ford. The Olds pulls into the garage next to it.

Vicky and Jack have just come in. Vicky is still hold- ing the ripped pants. HELEN, Vicky's mother, is maternal and very slender. She reaches for her coat, purse and knitting and looks Vicky over at the same time.
You didn't go to a costume party. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Cc) 7
How come you came home from one? Vicky holds the pants up for Helen to see. And then she mouths with Helen --
(continuing) I told you the pants were too tight.
I know you did, Mom. Thanks for sitting. (heading for the bedroom) Kids give you any trouble?
They never give me trouble. Helen looks at Jack.
(continuing; gesturing a fat body Do something with her.
I'm trying, Helen.

Im addition to the usual bedroom furnishings, an exer- cycle stands in one corner. Vicky comes into the room, goes to her dressing table, opens a bottom drawer and pushes things around until she finds a hidden candy bar. She starts to unwrap it, but the SOUND of the DOOR OPENING stops her. She drops the candy bar back into the drawer, and pushes it closed, as Jack comes in. He stands just inside the doorway, looking at her, and Vicky sees his reflection in the mirror. They're both uncomfortable, turn away. Then --
. I'm sorry...
So am I... (CONTINUED)
Cc)
She holds up a thumb toward him -- a private symbol they have. Jack holds his up -- as if to press the thumbs together -- but they're still across the room from each other.
Friends? A beat... and they move toward each other... just close enough to press thumbs together.
Friends. But the aura of the quarrel is still there -- they drop their hands, and don't know what to do next. Jack looks over the sari... tries for a grin.

(continuing) You know... you do look pretty sexy in that thing. Vicky grins, then in a comical, but sexy way, she hands him an end of the sari, and they dance around each other as he unwraps it, while they hum some torchy song. Then they go into each other's arms. They kiss, begin to touch each other, run their hands over each other. Jack's hand reaches Vicky's buttocks. He squeezes.
(continuing; murmuring) There's the beautiful bun that split the pants. Vicky freezes, and then, furious, she pushes him away.
You bought that pantsuit. I didn't.
You said you liked it.
I would have liked it a size larger.
You were going to lose weight by the party. (CONTINUED)
c) Cc) 8
I never said that. You said Thac.
You wanted that electronic calorie counter, and that exercycle thing. I got them for you.
I didn't want them. You wanted them.
What do you want? Ten cream puffs?
They're mostly air.
Vicky, it's not a joke. You're eating yourself right back to where you were when Danny was born. Why?
(comical question) I'm hungry?
(cynically paraphrasing) That's funny, you don't look hungry.
That's not funny!

No, it's not, Vicky! And it gets less funny by the pound. Vicky glares at him, and suddenly grabs a blanket off the bed. Jack, knowing what's coming, has his hand up ready -- Vicky throws the blanket, and he catches it.

Jack is asleep on the couch, his head completely covered by the blanket. LISA, 11, and DANNY, 9, in their pajamas, sneak up to the couch. Danny lifts the cover carefully, so they can see who it is. (CONTINUED)
(disappointed) It's Daddy.
That'll be a nickel. As they go back to the bedrooms --
Bet a dime the fight was about Mom eating too much. And they're gone. Jack wakes up, gets his bearings, realizing where he is and why. He gets up, stretches, and drops to the floor to do pushups.

Vicky wakes up, realizes she's alone in the bed -- remembers the fight, and pulls the covers up again. A beat, she throws off the covers, gets up, turns on the exercycle but doesn't get on it, and marches past it to the adjoining bathroom. We SEE her through the open door as she steps on the scale -- and groans.

A cake and cookies are in covered containers on the counters, sugared cereals are SEEN in open cupboards. The table is set for a fancy breakfast for four. Lisa puts the flower centerpiece in the middle, where three containers of syrup already stand along with jam and powdered sugar. Jack sets down a tray of hot pancakes. And Danny leads Vicky in. They're all dressed for the day, but Vicky is half asleep and in her robe.
(warily) Good morning.
We made breakfast.
I'm not hungry.
Aw, Mom... Daddy said we were all going to eat together. (CONTINUED)
Like we do every time you have a fight.
... I'll just have coffee. She sits down, and Jack pours coffee for her. She avoids Jack's eager look and sips at the coffee.
Danny and Jack are just finishing their breakfast. Lisa is poking at hers, half of it is still on the plate. Should we go out and let you talk now, like after all the fights?
Yes. Danny and Lisa get up as ~-
Are you driving, Daddy, like after all the --
Lisa, knock it off. Lisa shrugs, and starts out after Danny.
You didn't finish your breakfast.
I'm not hungry. And she goes. Vicky and Jack are alone. She's staring into her coffee... Jack looking at her... then --
Friends? He holds up his thumb... a beat... and Vicky presses hers against it.
Friends. (CONTINUED )
She pulls her hand away, uses both hands to hold the coffee cup, and looks away from him again.
... You want to meet me downtown and we'll go out to dinner?
Why is the peace offering food? I thought you wanted me to diet.
Well... you won't let me buy you clothes... Flowers! I'll buy you flowers.
I've got a garden full of flowers.
What do you want?
To wake up tomorrow a size 9.
Then go to Dr. Haymer... He did it for you before.
Yeah, when I was a kid, and a teenager, and after each baby. He's a lousy doctor. The disease keeps coming back... worse every time.

(takes her hand) But in between, Vick, when you get thin... you were gorgeous when we got married. . (moves in closer) You can look like that again. He leans over to kiss her -- just as Lisa comes in.
We're ready, Daddy.
Lisa, you've got lousy timing. (CONTINUED)
Sorry. And she goes. But she's broken the mood. Jack gets up.
Go to him, Vicky... You can be the sexiest, most beautiful woman in the world. _ He blows her a kiss, and goes. Vicky reaches up and grabs it, and mutters to herself.

Would it be okay if I was only the second most beautiful? She sits a moment, thinking. We HEAR the FRONT DOOR CLOSE. Without thinking, Vicky picks up the remaining cold pancake from Lisa's plate and begins to eat it.
of a normal heart and a heart covered with fat. STAY on that as:
A candy bar is 250 calories, a piece of pie is 300, a serving of peanuts, 400. WIDEN THE SHOT TO INCLUDE Vicky in DR. HAYMER's office, sitting across the desk from the doctor, an old femily friend.
(continuing) Calories are energy. If you don't use up the energy, it gtores itself in your body as at.
And 3500 calories of stored fat is one pound of body weight. I know all that, Dr. Haymer.
I know you know it. So why do you buy that stuff? (CONTINUED)
ao
I don't. I get it for the kids.
Who eats their leftovers?
(a beat, grins) Oh... leftovers...
(hands her a printed sheet) Vicky, go on a diet.
(looks at the form and puts it down) I went on this diet.
Went where? Off of it?

Busy -- women and men of all sizes, filling carts with food -- junk, health, lots of both. Above their heads, advertising banners offering a cornucopia of goodies -- desserts, starches, dietetic products, ete., etc. OVER all this:

Maybe it's my glands. We PUSH DOWN an aisle, diet foods on one side, gourmet bakery on the other, and FIND Vicky and Marge shopping. Vicky looks at the display of diet supplements with a before and after picture of a woman in profile, then joins Marge picking out baked goods as:
It's not glands. It's food. Too much food. The wrong kinds of food. Vicky, it's poison, it'll kill you.
So let me go back on those appetite depresents -- those amphetamines. (CONTINUED)
No, you got crazy on amphetamines. Vicky and Marge are near a slim demonstrator, offering tidbits of a rich cake. They stop to taste as:
So I asked him if I should take some tests or see an endocrinologist or something.
What'd he say? Marge takes two more samples, gives one to Vicky and they move on, past a huge man shoving cans of diet foods into his cart, as:

(imitating Haymer) If you want to spend your money, spend your money. But go on a diet. (looks at cake in her hand) I ean't start a diet in the middle of a day. : They round the corner to the candy aisle as:
(continuing) There ought to be a magic wand. A touch and the fat just melts off.
Or a touch and no one cares.
Vicky and Marge roll their overfilled carts out of the store, past the drugstore where a window display ad- vertises diet pills, and to Vicky's station wagon as:
Did you know they used to sell capsules of worms that would eat your fat from inside? Yuch.
Marge, we have to do something about ourselves! (CONTINUED)
Why? What's wrong with us?

On a street of small stores, we briefly NOTICE a bill- board advertising ice cream -- a bikinied girl eating a cone... and then FOCUS ON Vicky's station wagon, loaded with groceries, and Marge as passenger.
Wouldn't you like to look like Patty?

Did -you ever see how Patty eats? The station wagon turns a corner and pulls up into the line of cars double-parked.in front of an elementary school. Mostly mothers, a few fathers, sit at their wheels waiting.
Yeah, She doesn't.
Vicky and Marge are sharing a bag of doughnuts as:
What a lousy way to live.

Why? Patty's got it made... A great job, a macho live-in boyfriend, the same figure she had when she was eighteen. You know what I have? A 24 hour job -- being a maid to two kids, a house, and a husband who's looking for girls with figures like I had at eighteen.

You know what I have? I like myself. Which is more than either of you have. school. Immediately, a CACAPHONY OF HORNS is HEARD -- -_ The school BELL RINGS and the children burst out of th ~ parents summoning their kids. (CONTINUED)

The kids look about, confused. Danny seeks out Vicky's car from the school door, then seeing it, makes a beeline for the car. He dives into the back seat and lies down. We're vaguely AWARE of another boy, his age, Jeff, watching.
Let's go.

Mind if we wait for Lisa and Peggy? Jeff saunters to the car, and Danny cringes away from him. Jeff grins at Danny, looks at Vicky, then back at Danny. He puffs his cheeks out, comically grotesque, and as Danny leans out the window, Jeff waddles away.
(calling after Jeff) Creep!
What's all that about? Danny doesn't answer. Lisa and Marge's daughter, Peggy, appear at the school door, stop to talk to others. Danny leans over the front seat, and hits the HORN.
We're CLOSE ON the door on which is printed: DR. EUGENIA ROLLINS/ENDOCRINOLOGIST. An overweight man opens the door to go in, and we FOLLOW to:

The walls display charts and medical textbook pictures of weight related subjects: body types, good and bad foods, slogans, etc. Men, women and children, most of them overweight, studiously avoid speaking to each other. Vicky is as quiet as the rest, flipping through a medical journal, but actually studying those around her. A NURSE opens the inside door.
Mrs. Matthews. And Vicky goes inside.
DR. ROLLINS is a small compact woman. She's business~- like, and yet gentle, as:

Over half the people in this country weigh more than they should. And they spend 10 billion dollars every year on fad diets, gadgets, pills, books, clinics. All they really need is to eat fewer calories.
But, sometimes isn't it something the body is doing wrong?
Very, very few cases are due to body irregularity.
But my tests... didn't they show anything?

Your blood pressure is 130 over 95, it could be lower, but it's normal, Your sugar level is 120. 100 is better, but it's normal. But if you gain more weight, those figures could change -- drastically.
What about my glands?
Sorry. The only thing you can blame is your fatty cells.
(a reprieve, she thinks) Yeah?
We're all born with a certain amount of fatty cells. There are two times in our lives when they multiply. If we're fat as toddlers, or in our late teens. (CONTINUED)
She shows
(sinks) Guilty.

Once they're there, they stay there. Vicky the chart -- two sketches of fatty cells -- the sketch of the empty cells is small, the one with the filled cells is large, but both contain the same number of cells. She shrugs
(continuing) You see, if you keep them empty, they stay small, and you stay slim. But if -you fill them up...
(really shaken now) What can I do?
Take care of yourself.
I'm too busy taking care of everyone else.

{takes a diet sheet from drawer, the same one Dr. Haymer gave Vicky) You have time to go on a thousand calorie diet. And do aerobic exercises -- jog, swim, bike, jump rope. That will change your metabolism and burn the calories off faster... But most important, Vicky. Get at the source. Why?
(this is the nitty gritty, she's upset) I don't know why. (CONTINUED)
Find out. I'm no psychologist, but I know people usually overeat for emotional reasons. Because they're unhappy, or to make up for something else they're lacking.
Or maybe it's just a vice, like drinking or drugs... only it shows more.
Then get rid of it. Try a group . Weight Watchers or Overeaters Anonymous or Calorie Counters. Vicky looks more and more overwhelmed.

It's early evening. Jack and Lisa are working on the dining room table. Lisa, on homework; Jack, pay- ing bills. The room is adjacent to the kitchen, so that at some ANGLES we can SEE Vicky in there, making dinner. The counter is filled with riches for tonight -- mashed potatoes, sauces, a cake. Vicky is prepar- ing garlic toast, wets a finger to pick up 4 erumb, and eats it as:
So join one of them.
You know what they cost?
Whatever. I'11 pay.
You're still grumbling about paying for the gym.
$300 a year for four years! And you never use it!
(comes to the door) I never wanted it! (MORE) (CONTINUED)
It was one of your. 'helpful' hints! Like that damned exercycle in the bedroom.
And you never use that either!
. Are you going to fight? Lisa -- TACK
Bye... LIS She gathers her books quickly and goes, as --
I don't want to fight with you, Jack,
I know. You want a magic wand.
(trying to be funny) You think if they could go to the moon --
Vicky. Go to a diet club. A beat, Vicky shrugs and goes back into the kitchen.
I'm not a joiner. Jack follows her, and we FOLLOW.
(continuing) You want roquefort on the salad?
Vicky, go somewhere... before you turn into a Mack truck! Vicky freezes. And Jack could bite his tongue --
(continuing) I'm sorry. But Vicky is taking off her apron. (CONTINUED)
(continuing) Where are you going?
Somewhere! As ordered! She throws the apron at him and marches into the din- ing room. Jack follows, and we FOLLOW.
What about dinner?
as Lisa appears, playing the "sweet child."
I'll make it, Daddy. Vicky hears that, grows even more angry, as she marches into her bedroom and slams the door.

The gym is filled with men and women in sweatsuits, a few with weight belts, some of the really svelte women are in leotards, and all the heavy people are sweating profusely. They follow the male instructor through a rigorous exercise, bouncing in place in a jogging-like movement, to recorded MUSIC, and keeping up with vary- ing degrees of success, as we PAN:
(imitating Lisa) I'll make it, Daddy... the fink.

Let her. Let them all take turns cooking, and let Jack do the chauffeuring, baby sit a couple of nights so you can get out. And now we're on Vicky and Patty, next to each other. Patty is gorgeous in her leotard, and doing her exer- cise with ease. Vicky, in a sweatsuit, is barely mov- ing through it, breathing heavily. (CONTINUED)
(continuing; cynically) You don't have to be the sweet, self-sacrificing housewife every minute of the day.
Yes, I do... Jack's entitled to a good housewife or a good-looking . wife. TI have to be at least one of then. She stops for a breath, as the rest of the class keeps going.
What about what you're entitled to?
(trying the exercise again) I've got it.
What?
Kids, husband, home... ‘PATTY Is it what you want? New exercise -- harder -- sit-ups -- and Vicky can only get her head and shoulders off the floor. She hesi- tates, then nods, yes.
(continuing) Are you ever going back to work? You were a damned good advertising artist.
That was 12 years ago. The thought depresses her. The class is getting into shoulder stands for bicycling. Patty gets into it easily. (CONTINUED)
You going to just sit there? Vicky tries it -- once, twice... a third time. She rolls over, too far, and does a clumsy backward somer- sault. And then lies there, defeated.
Oh, the hell with it.

The SOUND of EXERCISE MUSIC is still HEARD, as Vicky, worn out, almost limps out of the gym. As she turns toward the parking lot to one side, we WIDEN THE SHOT TO INCLUDE the store between the gym and the parking lot -- an ice cream shop. Vicky gets just past it, hesitates, looks at the store, hungrily.

Pictures of luscious ice cream combinations line the walls. Vicky, wedged into a half-armed student chair, about to attack a large sundae complete with trimmings, scoops up the cherry, and when it's halfway to her mouth --

a jolly, very overweight women in her mid-30's, sits at right angles to Vicky. Vicky sees her when she lifts her head to eat the cherry. Vicky hesitates -- it's as if she's seen a mirror image of herself -- and she doesn't like it. Joyce looks up -- their eyes catch, and they're embarrassed. They've been caught in the act. Finally --
Don’t eat the cherry. Red dye number two, It's bad for you. A beat -- and they both laugh. Vicky shrugs a "what the hell" and digs in. They go on eating as:
You live around here?
Of course not. I wouldn't eat ice cream where people know me. They might think I'm fat. (CONTINUED)
They go on eating. Joyce finishes, struggles to get out of the chair, starts to leave, then stops for:
(continuing) My name is Joyce and I'm a compulsive overeater. That's how we say it at 0.A.
You belong to Overeaters Anonymous?
Did, Also Weight Watchers, Calorie Counters and TOPS. And as you can see, I gained a great deal from all of them. Vicky grins, laughs, and in a moment, they're both giggling uncontrollably.

location: THE STREET OUTSIDE THE ICE CREAM STORE

text: Vicky and Joyce leave the store together, as if they're great, old friends, and walk toward the parking lot.
Then there were only three left, and I couldn't serve that to six women, sO --
You polished them off, and went to the store for more.
Yeah. I was so sick the next day --
Did it stop you from eating? Vicky doesn't need to answer... they walk a minute, then --
The doctor said I should figure out why... and I thought of a million reasons... all phony. (CONTINUED)
oD)
I know why I eat... it's the only pleasure I have. They've reached Joyce's car.
(continuing) Well... bon appetit. She starts getting into the car, and Vicky reaches out impulsively to stop her.
Joyce, can I call you?
For the next ice cream sundae?
Or the next confessional, which ever comes first. Joyce digs into her purse for pencil or paper, as --
You'll never use this.

Probably not. She takes the slip of paper with Joyce's phone number on it, and Joyce gets into the car. Vicky watches as she drives off, then looks at the phone number, puts it into her purse, and starts toward her own car.

Lisa sits in front of the TV eating popcorn, and watching an old "Lucy" or ? rerun -- a funny dinner scene. But she's turned to what Jack and Vicky are saying. Vicky has just come in, and Jack is leading her toward Danny's room, as --
He wouldn't tell me. He just ran into his room and slammed the door. But you should have seen him. (CONTINUED)
He looks terrible.
Of all the nights for you not to be here. Vicky goes to Danny's door and knocks.
Danny?
Go away!

Danny is in his pajamas, and huddled into the bed, with his back to Vicky. She picks up his shirt from the floor, notices the rips, dirt and blood on it, and goes with it to the bed. She sits down and turns him toward her. Danny has made a childish, unsuccess~ ful attempt to clean his face, but the dirt, and remnants of a bloody nose are still SEEN.
... How's the other guy?
I barely touched him... He's got the longest arms!
Who?
Jeff Hauser! He didn't mean to tell her. He turns away, and pushes down into the covers.
The creep?
I'll get him back...
For what? (CONTINUED)
For... for giving me a bloody nose, and tearing my shirt and --
For what, Danny? A beat... and Danny has to let it out -- on a sob.

He said you had to go through doors sideways... he said... boy was I lucky, I didn't have a mother, I had an elephant... he said... And he can't talk any more, he's sobbing too hard. Vicky holds back her own tears... but the pain is obvious. Vicky holds her arms out to him, and Danny goes into them. She holds him, rocking him... as he sobs and she bites at her lips. FADE OUT.

A busy place; waiters carry trays heaped with rich food, pastry carts stand waiting, menus are huge. Baskets piled high with homemade rolls are on every table. A fashion MODEL in a flowing, long gown poses for the women at one table, and a slender luncher, watching, rejects a basket of hot biscuits/rolls offered by a waiter. We FOLLOW the Model toward another table, where someone lathers a roll with butter... and then MOVE PAST that toward another table where Vicky and Marge are finishing their lunches. Vicky's eating a tuna salad, and Marge, a club sandwich with French fries. A WAITRESS refills their coffee cups.
Oh, didn't you get rolls?
Yes, but I didn't want -- But the Waitress is gone. Marge starts to ladle sugar into her coffee, as Vicky squeezes some lemon onto her salad and picks up what she's been saying:

(continuing) I didn’t know what to say to Danny. ‘I'm not fat?' ‘It's okay that I'm fat?' ‘Jeff's a stinking brat and you should beat him up'?... which is what T wanted to say. Marge, why don't you use artificial sweetener in your coffee?

That stuff kills rats. Two men take the table behind Vicky; the one back to back with her, pushing his chair quite close in order to sit down. The Waitress appears with two baskets of rolls, putting one on the men's table, and one on icky's.
